revision.comment: Necrothesp moved page [[John Daley (aviator)]] to [[John Daley (RAF officer)]]: normal
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person | name =John Albert Edward Robertson Daley | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1898|2|5|df=yes}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1918|7|8|1898|2|5|df=yes}} | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial = | birth_place = [[Kingston, Jamaica]] | death_place = France | placeofburial_coordinates = | nickname = | allegiance =United Kingdom | branch =British Army
Royal Air Force | serviceyears =1916–1918 | rank =Lieutenant | unit =[[British West Indies Regiment]]
[[No. 13 Squadron RAF|No. 13 Squadron RFC]]
[[No. 24 Squadron RAF]] | commands = | battles = | awards =[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] | relations = | laterwork = }} Lieutenant '''John Albert Edward Robertson Daley''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|DFC}} (5 February 1898 – 8 July 1918) was a British [[World War I]] [[flying ace]] credited with six aerial victories.{{cite web |url= http://www.theaerodrome.com/aces/england/daley.php |title=John Albert Edward Robertson Daley |work=theaerodrome.com |year=2014 |accessdate=21 August 2014}} Daley was born in Kingston, Jamaica, the son of George E. Daley of [[New Market, Jamaica|New Market]], [[Saint Elizabeth Parish|St. Elizabeth]], Jamaica, and attended the [[Munro College|Potsdam School]].{{cite web |url=http://www.jamaicanfamilysearch.com/Members/who19_05.htm |title=Commissioned officers from Jamaica died World War I |first=Patricia |last=Jackson |work=Jamaican Family Search|year=2014 |accessdate=21 August 2014}} He enlisted on 19 January 1916 as a private in the 2nd Jamaica Battalion, [[British West Indies Regiment]], and on 6 March 1916 he was confirmed as a temporary second lieutenant.{{London Gazette |date=27 June 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29643 |startpage=6418 }} Note: The London Gazette gives his name as "Daly" throughout. The same day he was one of 25 officers and 1,115 [[Other ranks (UK)|other ranks]] of the Third Jamaica Contingent who embarked on the SS ''Verdala'' at Kingston. Owing to the threat of German [[U-boat]]s ''Verdala'' was routed to England via [[Halifax (former city)|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]]. En route it ran into a blizzard. ''Verdala'' was not properly heated and the soldiers had not been issued with sufficient warm clothing, causing 600 cases of [[Hypothermia|exposure]] and [[frostbite]], and five deaths. On arrival at Halifax 106 men were hospitalized.{{cite web |url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C10312366 |title=Forwards nominal roll of the third Jamaica contingent of the British West India Regiment |work=[[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]] |year=2014 |accessdate=12 November 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~jamwgw/3contin.htm |title=3rd Jamaica Contingent, WWI, extracts from the ''Daily Gleaner'' |work=rootsweb.ancestry.com |year=2014 |accessdate=12 November 2014}}{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/worldwars/wwone/west_indies_01.shtml |title=World Wars: A White Man's War? World War One and the West Indies |first=Glenford D. |last=Howe |work=BBC History |date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=12 November 2014}} On 6 April 1917 Daley was appointed a flying officer (observer) in the Royal Flying Corps, with seniority from 27 December 1916,{{London Gazette |date=27 April 1917 |supp=yes |issue=30038 |startpage=4034 |nolink=yes}} serving in No. 13 Squadron. On 27 December 1917 he was appointed a flying officer,{{London Gazette |date=18 January 1918 |supp=yes |issue=30486 |startpage=1060 |nolink=yes}} serving in No. 24 Squadron, flying a [[Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5|S.E.5a]]. Between March and July 1918 he shot down five aircraft and a [[Observation balloon|kite balloon]], but was killed in action only a week after his final victory. ==Awards== His award of the Distinguished Flying Cross was gazetted a month after his death. :T./Lt. John Albert Edward Robertson Daley (formerly British West Indies Regiment.) :This officer has destroyed five enemy aeroplanes and two kite balloons, displaying marked skill and daring in these several actions, and also in attacking troops close to the ground.{{London Gazette |issue=30827 |date=2 August 1918 |startpage=9199 |supp=yes |nolink=yes }} ==References== {{Research help|Mil}} {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Daley, John}} [[Category:1898 births]] [[Category:1918 deaths]] [[Category:People from Kingston, Jamaica]] [[Category:British World War I flying aces]] [[Category:British West Indies Regiment soldiers]] [[Category:Royal Flying Corps officers]] [[Category:Royal Air Force personnel of World War I]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)]] [[Category:People educated at Munro College]]
